awd_abstract_narration: This award is made as part of the FY 2017 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Oleg Lazarev is "Weinstein Fillings, H-Principles, and Exotic Symplectic Structures." The host institution for the fellowship is Columbia University, and the sponsoring scientist is Mohammed Abouzaid.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Symplectic geometry arose from classical Newtonian mechanics and has recently impacted many other areas of mathematics like low-dimensional topology,  algebraic geometry, and representation theory. During this fellowship, the PI studied Weinstein domains, which are symplectic spaces that can be built out of certain elementary pieces and hence are easier to work with and compute. One of the PI's main results  is an upper bound on the number of elementary pieces needed to construct a symplectic manifold, addressing a question of Eliashberg from the 90s. The PI also discovered that this result is closely connected to a result of Thomason in algebraic K-theory, which shows that  abstract algebraic constructions called categories can also be generated by relatively few objects. During this fellowship, the PI also worked to create bridges between `rigid' and `flexible' symplectic geometry, a dichotomy which arose due to Gromov's foundational work thirty years ago. In a collaboration with Sylan, the PI constructed a sequence of symplectic manifolds that interpolate between rigid and flexible Weinstein domains and are indexed by collections of primes, analogous to a construction in classical topology. The PI also used flexible techniques of constructing new rigid symplectic manifolds out of old ones.  This also led to a number of results in contact topology (the odd-dimensional cousin of symplectic manifolds):  symplectic caps for all contact manifolds, codimension 2 contact embeddings, contact surgery decompositions, and contact manifolds with many fillings.

The PI also co-organized the symplectic seminar at Columbia and a learning seminar at Harvard; the PI also began co-organizing a conference on contact topology and dynamics for spring 2022. He also gave a number of expository talks on geometry to undergraduate and first- year graduate students. The PI's work is publicly available on the arxiv as follows:

https://arxiv.org/abs/1808.03676

https://arxiv.org/abs/1910.01101

https://arxiv.org/abs/1808.05993

https://arxiv.org/abs/1810.11728

https://arxiv.org/abs/2009.09490


Last Modified: 09/17/2021
Modified by: Oleg Lazarev
